pgTitle: List of ghost towns in Kansas

rows.text: Most of the houses were demolished or moved in the 1950s. The old Co-op remains and still bears the town name. Large berm south of the co-op is what is left from the demolition 38.174742,-98.962701
Townsite was abandoned, only ruins remain
Was a health resort that lasted into the 1930s.
Still on maps but little remains
A trading post was established on the site in 1852
Was actually a trading post from 1826-1828
A couple buildings and a cemetery remain
On private property and not accessible
The old territorial capitol building still stands is well-preserved
Located on Corps land and is easily accessible.
Abandoned for the construction of Tuttle Creek Lake.
Santa Fe Trail wagon swales, a roadside park, cemetery and the well-preserved battlefield site remain and are open to public.
There is still a small population in the area.
Several ruins of the downtown and old consolidated school remain.
Several buildings remain abandoned in the area.
Few remains exist but a monument to Diamond Springs was erected in Diamond Springs Cemetery
Empire City was annexed to Galena in 1907.
Ella Wilson was the founder of the town and when she died in 1913, the town died with her.
Octagon City was a social experiment where the settlers of the town vowed to eat no meat. The town was so called because the main streets were laid out in an octagon.
The site of Cofachiqui was demolished when a cement company bought the land.
Townsite is now on private property and inaccessible.
A few ruins and structures still survive.
Cave Springs was established as a "health" resort. The resort failed in the 1880s when people starting questioning the springs' healing properties. The town was officially vacated in 1949.
Townsite is now on private property.
Some houses and foundations remain along with a cemetery.
A church, some houses and a cemetery remain.
Townsite is now on private property.
A beautiful Catholic church and cemetery are all that remain.
Townsite is now on private property.
Freeport is the smallest incorporated town in Kansas.
Old roads and some structures still remain.
A railroad town, founded in 1889. The property fell into private hands and was plowed under.
The townsite become the private property of Pat Reilly, who plowed it under, until 1972 when it was sold to the Brown brothers.
Nothing remains of the townsite and is now on private property.
A small population exists and several buildings remain.
Nothing remains of the townsite except a community building.
Beersheba was established as an experimental Jewish agricultural community.
Battled with Ravanna for county seat of Garfield County, which ended in 1893 when Garfield County was annexed to Finney County.
The old Ulysses townsite is currently on private property but the "new" Ulysses site has an estimated population of 5,557 as of 2008.
In 1908, Ulysses moved three miles down the road to a new location in an attempt to not pay back bonds that had become due.
Nothing remains and a portion of the townsite is on private property.
A small population remains in the area.

Six-Mile House, so called because of its distance from Wyandotte (Kansas City) on Leavenworth Rd, was the headquarters of the Free-State 'Redlegs' who guarded the border of Kansas from pro-slave incursions.
Padonia lies among a cluster of houses and farm fields.
Padonia was the site of a bloodless skirmish in the 1850s called the Battle of Padonia.
The cemetery, church, town hall and schoolhouse have all been restored and well-kept.
A small cemetery and church mark the townsite.
All that remains is the Antioch Cemetery.
Bigelow was demolished during construction of Tuttle Creek Lake.
Fort Riley has now expanded into what was Bala.
A community existed in the area before Lone Star was organized. A post office was formed in 1875 under Bond, then Gideon. The name Lone Star was chosen in the 1890s.
Potwin was annexed to Topeka in 1899.
Auburndale is currently a neighborhood in Topeka and is commemorated by Auburndale Park.
Nothing remains of the townsite except some ruins and the cemetery.
Some old buildings, ruins and a church still stand in the area.
A small population and some abandoned businesses remain in the area.
A small population (approx. 20) remains in the area.
In 1905, most cabins were burned down. Frank Cotton discovered that the boards on his house were soaked with kerosene. Cotton saved his house but the remaining cabins burned to the ground.
Nothing remains of the townsite except Delos Johnson's (the town founder) house and a neglected cemetery.

The Cato Historical Preservation Association meets at 6:30 pm on the fourth Tuesday of each month at Arcadia Community Center, Arcadia, Kansas. The old school has been restored. Cato Christian Church is in good repair, but closed. A community reunion is held yearly.|
A small population remains in the area.
A small population remains along with some shotgun houses and some building ruins.
Very little remains of the townsite.
Due to years of mining in the area, the land in and around Treece is unstable and contaminated which had led to the citizens wanting the government to buy their land so that they can move.
Votaw was an experimental colony founded by African-Americans. After 1900, the population slowly moved elsewhere. The last building burned down in 1915.
Currently on property known as the Kalida Farm.
Only a hotel remains that is being used as a residence.
Some structures still remain. A transmission shop is open.
A plaque was dedicated in 1990 commemorating Strawberry.
A church, now used as a town hall, and a few houses, is all that remains.
A few buildings and population remain.
A monument was erected in 1936. Abram was the first Lincoln County Seat.
Some abandoned buildings and ruins remain.
All of Hitschmann is currently on private property.
Frederick is the second-smallest incorporated town in Kansas.
Some ruins of the old cement company remain as do some abandoned houses and other buildings.
Bluff City was originally founded as a fraud in 1873 to swindle money from the Kansas legislature. The first settlers in the area didn't arrive until 1876.
Little remains of old Clear Water but Clearwater has an estimated (as of 2008) population of 2,405.
A small population (approx. 20) remains as well as some houses and other buildings.
A few homes and abandoned buildings remain.
Wait Till the Sun Shines, Nellie
An old schoolhouse, church, and abandoned grocery store remain but most of Lerado is now farmland.
Old Kiowa was abandoned when the railroad was built four miles to the south and a new Kiowa was established.
A small population (approx. 30) remains. The United Methodist Church is open.
A small resident population of about 40 remains.
Some ruins and abandoned buildings remain.
The site of Kanona is currently on private property.
A small resident population remains along with some ruins and abandoned buildings.
A small population and some abandoned buildings and ruins still remain.
Nothing remains of the townsite but the Pardee Cemetery.
Nothing remains of the old fort.
Some ruins and street grades are all that remain.
The Kansas City Metro area has grown into the area of Springdale.
Some ruins and abandoned building remain on what used to be Main Street.
A small population remains as does some buildings.
The townsite is under the waters of the Tuttle Creek Reservoir.
Aubry was located around 192nd Street and Metcalf.
Old residences, streets and other buildings remain in and around Clearview City.
The Ransom house still stands as does some other houses and buildings.
A couple of churches, some houses and the old schoolhouse remain.
Originally called Deer Creek Community until 1899 when the post office opened, the post office closed in 1903.
A small population remains on the north edge of the John Redmond Reservoir.
Ruins of the Havana Stage Station and hotel remain and a sign has been posted on the site.
Nothing remains of the townsite, only Rochester Cemetery and Rochester Road in North Topeka mark the site.
Nothing remains of the townsite however Wanamaker Road, Topeka's main western edge road, bears its name.
After a tornado destroyed the town in 1917, it was not rebuilt.
Only a small cemetery marks the townsite.
A small population remains as well as the ruins of Main Street and a high school gymnasium.
Nothing remains of the townsite except an old well.
Nothing remains of the townsite except for a church & the old Lyona School built in 1870.
The town barely got started and was abandoned soon after its founding.
The town was surveyed but soon after a local child died after arrived in Buchanan, the town was abandoned.
An old blacksmith shop still stands but nothing else remains.
Ironically, in 1901, a railroad built a depot at Terra Cotta despite nothing being there. It was moved in 1934.
The Idavale Ranch is located on the Kanapolis Reservoir Legacy Trail, along with Terra Cotta.
A small population and building ruins remain.
After the founder, Roger Cain, died, the town was slowly abandoned. Nothing remains of the townsite.
An old grain elevator and a couple of houses remain.
The town never actually existed despite being named the county seat in 1871.
A small population (approx. 20) remains along with a dam built in 1882.
Nothing remains of the townsite, the town was wiped off the map by a tornado.
In 1910, the people of Sherlock renamed the town Holcomb, which still exists.
Some ruins remain in the area.
Some ruins of old stone houses remain.
Nothing remains of the townsite except for a Santa Fe Trail marker and a cemetery.
The town was short-lived but the post office existed decades longer than the actual town.
The town was abandoned when Meade Center won the county seat. Nothing remains but a main street through Meade is named Carthage.
Renamed Artesian City from Spring Lake in 1887, nothing remains of the townsite.
The main street and an old schoolhouse remain.
The ruins of a schoolhouse remain in the area.
A cemetery, ruins of an old church and an abandoned stone house are all that remain of the town.
A small population remains along with an old cemetery, schoolhouse and the natural mounds the town was named for.
Muncie is now a part of suburban Kansas City.
Was the county seat from 1861 until 1864.
A cemetery and some farms are all that remain.
Little remains of the townsite, a small population remains.
The entire town was auctioned off in 1909.
Black Wolf is currently on private property.
The last building marking the site burned down in 1967.
Little remains of the townsite, a small population remains.
Some houses and ruins remain in the area.
All that remains is an abandoned grain elevator.
Structures still stand, and two families still live on the townsite.
Town has been completely vacant for a few years. Six buildings remain standing on the townsite, including an elevator & old school.
Two vacant grain elevators, two vacant houses, an old school, and a few ruins remain in this town.
